elements.content: Two new ligands N,N,N′,N′-tetraisopropyl/tetraisobutyl-3,4-pyridinedicarboxamide L1–L2 and six of their Hg­(II)­X2 complexes (where X = Cl–, Br–, and I–) have been synthesized and characterized. Single crystal X-ray structures of three complexes of L1 (1–3) with HgCl2/Br2/I2 and two complexes of L2 (4–5) with HgCl2/Br2 show that these are two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymers, with three different (one new) topologies and five coordinated Hg­(II) ions, in square pyramidal coordination. Complex 6, of L2 with HgI2, is a dimer with a four coordinated tetrahedral Hg­(II) ion. The ligands behave as two- or three-connecting linkers for forming coordination polymers (CPs) but only one-connector in the dimer. Various types of hydrogen bonding and other noncovalent interactions have been calculated, analyzed, and discussed for all the complexes and the ligand L1. Although the large size and soft character of iodide coupled with the steric effects of large isobutyl groups are mainly responsible for a change in the primary structure of 6, a significant role of the semilocalized LP···π and C–H···O noncovalent interactions into this has also been found. The latter transform this dimer into a stable 2D hydrogen-bonded network instead of a coordination polymer. The unique halide bridged 2D structure of 1 forms one-dimensional zig-zag chains of metal ions owing to the mercurophilic interactions. Weaker interactions of the same kind further extend along the basic skeleton of 2D CP and are facilitated by LP···π, strong C–H···Cl and C–H···N­(py) interactions.

Single crystal X-ray structures of three complexes of L1 (1-3) with HgCl2/Br2/I2 and two complexes of L2 (4-5) with HgCl2/Br2 show that these are two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymers, with three different (one new) topologies and five coordinated Hg(II) ions, in square pyramidal coordination. Various types of hydrogen bonding and other noncovalent interactions have been calculated, analyzed, and discussed for all the complexes and the ligand L1. Weaker interactions of the same kind further extend along the basic skeleton of 2D CP and are facilitated by LP⋅⋅⋅π, strong C-H⋅⋅⋅Cl and C-H⋅⋅⋅N(py) interactions.

elements.content: New ligands L1−L2 and six of their Hg­(II)­X2 complexes (where X = Cl−, Br−, and I−) have been synthesized and characterized. The primary and secondary structures of the self-assembled systems are shown to be an interesting outcome of the divergent ligands, coordination mode of anions, steric factors, and noncovalent interactions. The ligand versus anion competition is imminent when steric congestion becomes overwhelming.

elements.content: Coordination network solids, of which coordination polymers (CPs) and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) form a class and subclass respectively, are compounds relentlessly attracting scientific attention for the past few decades. They are ideal examples of inorganic crystal engineering for having utilized various noncovalent interactions to obtain technologically useful materials with various dimensionalities and topologies and provide an important interface between synthetic and material chemistry. Nonporous coordination polymers though may have lesser applications than MOFs but are structurally equally interesting, and the simplicity of their self-assembly coupled with ease of structural modifications makes them ubiquitous in nature, especially the one-dimensional CPs. Moreover, various interchain/interlayer, metal domain (M···M, M–H···X), ligand domain (D–H···A, anion···π, halogen bonding, halogen···halogen), and periphery domain (C–H···X, C–H···π, lone pair···π, etc.) hydrogen bonding and other noncovalent interactions supplement the coordination bonding to generate compounds with higher dimensionalites. The strength, directionality, and distance dependence of most of these intermolecular interactions not only dictate the primary structure but may guide the secondary structure as well, by influencing molecular assembly and crystal packing. Therefore, a detailed study of various noncovalent interactions shaping the final outcome of a self-assembly process is the soul of crystal engineering.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination network solids, of which coordination polymers (CPs) and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) form a class and subclass respectively, are compounds relentlessly attracting scientific attention for the past few decades. They are ideal examples of inorganic crystal engineering for having utilized various noncovalent interactions to obtain technologically useful materials with various dimensionalities and topologies and provide an important interface between synthetic and material chemistry. Nonporous coordination polymers though may have lesser applications than MOFs but are structurally equally interesting, and the simplicity of their self-assembly coupled with ease of structural modifications makes them ubiquitous in nature, especially the one-dimensional CPs. Moreover, various interchain/interlayer, metal domain (M⋅⋅⋅M, M-H⋅⋅⋅X), ligand domain (D-H⋅⋅⋅A, anion⋅⋅⋅π, halogen bonding, halogen⋅⋅⋅halogen), and periphery domain (C-H⋅⋅⋅X, C-H⋅⋅⋅π, lone pair⋅⋅⋅π, etc.) hydrogen bonding and other noncovalent interactions supplement the coordination bonding to generate compounds with higher dimensionalites. The strength, directionality, and distance dependence of most of these intermolecular interactions not only dictate the primary structure but may guide the secondary structure as well, by influencing molecular assembly and crystal packing. Therefore, a detailed study of various noncovalent interactions shaping the final outcome of a self-assembly process is the soul of crystal engineering.

elements.content: The dimensionality and topology resulting from coordination polymerization and/or hydrogen bonding are dependent on many factors such as the type of ligand, metal ion, anion, solvent, temperature, etc. The use of divergent polydentate ligands in metal coordination instead of traditional convergent chelating ligands can be very helpful in extending the coordination network through space in one-, two-, or three-dimensional (1D, 2D, and 3D) architectures and is a good innovation for crystal engineering of coordination networks. The spherical d10 metal ions, due to the absence of crystal field stabilization energy, have flexible coordination geometries and are amenable to linear and other distorted geometries which facilitate the formation of 1D CPs. On the other hand, general lability of these ions renders the coordinate bonds reversible, permitting rearrangement of metal and ligands to acquire highly ordered 2D and 3D networks also.

The spherical d10 metal ions, due to the absence of crystal field stabilization energy, have flexible coordination geometries and are amenable to linear and other distorted geometries which facilitate the formation of 1D CPs. On the other hand, general lability of these ions renders the coordinate bonds reversible, permitting rearrangement of metal and ligands to acquire highly ordered 2D and 3D networks also.

elements.content: Literature shows that a lot of quality work has been done regarding the self-assembly of pyridine-based carboxamides derived from primary amines and various acids like nicotinic acid, isonicotinic acid, and 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid. A closer look, however, shows that fully (alkyl/phenyl) substituted amide derivatives of various pyridine carboxylic acids also provide the necessary rigidity, binding sites, and intermolecular interactions to allow the creation of CPs. However, not much has been reported on the coordination behavior of such amides. Therefore, a few years back, one of us and Kapoor et al. undertook work on N,N-dialkyl/diphenyl-nicotinamide, -isonicotinamide, -picolinamide, and N,N,N′,N′-tetraalkyl-2,6-pyridinemono/dicarboxamides. Whereas nicotinamides and isonicotinamide derivatives (divergent polydentate ligands) generated many interesting 1D, 2D, and 3D coordination/H-bonded architectures and showed remarkable magnetic properties for cobalt­(II) and copper­(II) complexes, those of picolinamides and 2,6-pyridinedicarboxamides (convergent polydentate ligands) generally yielded zero-dimensional coordination compounds. Working on these lines, we now report for the first time a series of six Hg­(II)­X2 complexes of two new N,N,N′,N′-tetraisopropyl/tetraisobutyl-3,4-pyridinedicarboxamide ligands L1–L2, five of which form 2D CPs. In contrast to N,N,N′,N′-tetraalkyl-2,6-pyridine dicarboxamides, these ligands offer three divergent coordination sites and may bind in various coordination modes ().

However, not much has been reported on the coordination behavior of such amides. Therefore, a few years back, one of us and Kapoor et al. undertook work on N,N-dialkyl/diphenyl-nicotinamide, -isonicotinamide, -picolinamide, and N,N,N',N'-tetraalkyl-2,6-pyridinemono/dicarboxamides. In contrast to N,N,N',N'-tetraalkyl-2,6-pyridine dicarboxamides, these ligands offer three divergent coordination sites and may bind in various coordination modes ().

elements.content: Hg­(II) is the metal ion of our choice (vide supra) and also for the reason that there are far fewer of its CPs known in comparison to its congeners. The large vdW radius of mercury­(II) enables it to have a larger number of noncovalent interactions, resulting in better opportunities for newer architectures. The majority of Hg­(II) CPs are 1D in nature largely because of its large size, lower coordination number, and inclination of Hg­(II) for tetrahedral coordination, and only a few examples are known for 2D CPs. Our pick of halides as counteranions is inspired by their known polarizability and anisotropy and by the proven role of anions, in general and halides in particular, in the crystal engineering of Hg­(II) compounds where halide bridging is ubiquitous. Binding to a metal ion increases the polarity and tunes the basicity of halide ions and amide oxygens, respectively. This, coupled with the electron-deficient pyridine ring and abundant peripheral alkyl groups, offers just the right combination for generating a large number of C–H···X/O/π, π···π and lone pair···π interactions. The cumulative “Gulliver effect” of these weak interactions is envisaged to support, direct, or even dictate the dimensionality and topology of these coordination compounds, leading to diverse supramolecular architectures.

The majority of Hg(II) CPs are 1D in nature largely because of its large size, lower coordination number, and inclination of Hg(II) for tetrahedral coordination, and only a few examples are known for 2D CPs. Our pick of halides as counteranions is inspired by their known polarizability and anisotropy and by the proven role of anions, in general and halides in particular, in the crystal engineering of Hg(II) compounds where halide bridging is ubiquitous. Binding to a metal ion increases the polarity and tunes the basicity of halide ions and amide oxygens, respectively. This, coupled with the electron-deficient pyridine ring and abundant peripheral alkyl groups, offers just the right combination for generating a large number of C-H⋅⋅⋅X/O/π, π⋅⋅⋅π and lone pair⋅⋅⋅π interactions. The cumulative "Gulliver effect" of these weak interactions is envisaged to support, direct, or even dictate the dimensionality and topology of these coordination compounds, leading to diverse supramolecular architectures.

elements.content: L1 crystallizes in an orthorhombic non-centrosymmetric Pca21 space group. ORTEP representation (a) shows two crystallographically independent molecules (A and B) of the ligand L1 in the asymmetric unit. The torsion angles (C4–C3–C6–O1), (C1–C2–C13–O2), (C21–C22–C25–O3), and (C24–C23–C32–O4) are −105(1), −105(1), 104(1), and 103(1)°, respectively, and the dihedral angle (β) between the respective pyridine rings and amide groups () indicates that the amide groups are considerably twisted with respect to the pyridine rings and are almost perpendicular to each other. The carbonyl groups as well as the alkyl groups on the two arms are in an anti-conformation with respect to each other (b). This may be attributed to the steric factors due to the presence of isopropyl groups on the fully substituted amide groups, placed ortho to each other. Both A and B molecules form their own set of parallel helical chains, along the a axis due to C15–H15C···O1, C16–H16B···O1 and C30–H30B···O4, C31–H31C···O4 intermolecular hydrogen bonding, respectively. Since A and B are in a parallel but anti conformation with respect to each other, these two sets of helical chains are further joined to each other due to C21–H21···N1 and C18–H18C···N4 hydrogen bonding, to shape up helical tapes parallel to the a axis (). These tapes are in turn linked through C9–H9···O1, C27–H27···N4, and C24–H24···O3 interactions to propagate the supramolecular arrangement along the b axis generating a 2D network ().
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystal Structure of N,N,N',N'-Tetraisopropyl-3,4-pyridinedicarboxamide Ligand (L1)

 L1 crystallizes in an orthorhombic non-centrosymmetric Pca21 space group. ORTEP representation (a) shows two crystallographically independent molecules (A and B) of the ligand L1 in the asymmetric unit. The torsion angles (C4-C3-C6-O1), (C1-C2-C13-O2), (C21-C22-C25-O3), and (C24-C23-C32-O4) are -105(1), -105(1), 104(1), and 103(1)°, respectively, and the dihedral angle (β) between the respective pyridine rings and amide groups () indicates that the amide groups are considerably twisted with respect to the pyridine rings and are almost perpendicular to each other. The carbonyl groups as well as the alkyl groups on the two arms are in an anti-conformation with respect to each other (b). This may be attributed to the steric factors due to the presence of isopropyl groups on the fully substituted amide groups, placed ortho to each other. Both A and B molecules form their own set of parallel helical chains, along the a axis due to C15-H15C⋅⋅⋅O1, C16-H16B⋅⋅⋅O1 and C30-H30B⋅⋅⋅O4, C31-H31C⋅⋅⋅O4 intermolecular hydrogen bonding, respectively. Since A and B are in a parallel but anti conformation with respect to each other, these two sets of helical chains are further joined to each other due to C21-H21⋅⋅⋅N1 and C18-H18C⋅⋅⋅N4 hydrogen bonding, to shape up helical tapes parallel to the a axis (). These tapes are in turn linked through C9-H9⋅⋅⋅O1, C27-H27⋅⋅⋅N4, and C24-H24⋅⋅⋅O3 interactions to propagate the supramolecular arrangement along the b axis generating a 2D network ().

B - bridging, T - terminal, conf. - relative conformation, cood. - coordination, α = ∠CO–Hg, β = dihedral angle between py and amide groups, CN = coordination number.

The structure of this double salt is unique in the sense that there are [HgCl2] and [HgL1Cl2] moieties in the asymmetric unit of the complex 1 (a). The complex is a 2D coordination polymer (b) whose stepwise formation may be explained as follows. First the formation of a centrosymmetric dimer by joining of two [HgL1Cl2] units, through μ2-Cl3 bridges between two Hg2 ions takes place while the second chloride ion Cl4 is bonded terminally (). Each Hg2 ion in this dimer is five coordinated by three chlorides and pyridine nitrogen and one amide oxygen (O2). The ligand L1 is a two-connecting linker between two successive dimers and results in forming 1D ladder-like, polymeric chains of edge sharing, slightly distorted square pyramids (Addison parameter τ = 0.29), parallel to the a axis. Now the second moiety [HgCl2] forms a 1D, stair case type, polymeric chain of edge sharing octahedrons (c) parallel to the former by using μ2-Cl1 and Cl2 ions bridging between successive Hg1 ions. These two kinds of chains are in turn bonded to each other due to bridging through Cl3 and Cl4 ligands in μ3- and μ2-modes respectively, forming a 2D coordination polymer in the ab plane. Thus, in this 2D polymer all Cl– ions are in bridging mode. Topologically the structure is new, containing infinite layers of alternating stairs and ladders that form 4,5-connected 2-nodal net with a point symbol {3.55}­{32.43.54.6} (d).

Crystal Structure of [Hg(L1)Cl2][HgCl2] (1)

The structure of this double salt is unique in the sense that there are [HgCl2] and [HgL1Cl2] moieties in the asymmetric unit of the complex 1 (a). The complex is a 2D coordination polymer (b) whose stepwise formation may be explained as follows. First the formation of a centrosymmetric dimer by joining of two [HgL1Cl2] units, through μ2-Cl3 bridges between two Hg2 ions takes place while the second chloride ion Cl4 is bonded terminally (). Each Hg2 ion in this dimer is five coordinated by three chlorides and pyridine nitrogen and one amide oxygen (O2). The ligand L1 is a two-connecting linker between two successive dimers and results in forming 1D ladder-like, polymeric chains of edge sharing, slightly distorted square pyramids (Addison parameter τ = 0.29), parallel to the a axis. Now the second moiety [HgCl2] forms a 1D, stair case type, polymeric chain of edge sharing octahedrons (c) parallel to the former by using μ2-Cl1 and Cl2 ions bridging between successive Hg1 ions. These two kinds of chains are in turn bonded to each other due to bridging through Cl3 and Cl4 ligands in μ3- and μ2-modes respectively, forming a 2D coordination polymer in the ab plane. Thus, in this 2D polymer all Cl- ions are in bridging mode. Topologically the structure is new, containing infinite layers of alternating stairs and ladders that form 4,5-connected 2-nodal net with a point symbol {3.55}{32.43.54.6} (d).

elements.content: The conformation of L1 ligand is slightly changed in the complex. The amide groups are still perpendicular to the pyridine ring and in anti-conformation to each other (C5–C4–C6–O1 and C2–C3–C13–O2 torsion angles are 93.8(10) and 93.9(10)° and β of 80.4(6) and 81.8(5)°), but they are now rotated more with respect to pyridine rings. Various C–H···Cl interactions (vide infra) support this 2D coordination polymer ().

Crystal Structure of [Hg(L1)Br2] (2)

The asymmetric unit of the complex 2 is shown in a, while a perspective view (b) illustrates that Hg(II) ion is five-coordinated through two-connecting linker L1, a terminal Br2 and a bridging Br1 ions () forming a 2D CP of edge-sharing regular square pyramids (τ = 0.05) in the bc plane. Each Hg(II) ion in this 2D CP is bridged by two L1 molecules which are mutually twisted (~60°), forming "step shaped" 1D polymeric chains, running parallel to the c axis.

Terminal bromides are omitted.

elements.content: The centrosymmetrically related parallel chains then get linked to each other due to a Hg–Br1 bond generating (1 0 0) layers with three-connected uninodal net having a point symbol (63) and hcb type topology (c). The net contains 32-membered metallacyclic rings. Amide oxygen O2 remains free and is involved in hydrogen bonding interactions. The CP is strengthened by C16– H16C···Br1 hydrogen-bonding interactions (vide infra) () as well as by C–H···π interactions between alkyl group C12 and the pyridine (Table S1, SI). The amide groups of L1 are perpendicular to the pyridine ring (C2–C3–C6–O1 and C5–C4–C13–O2 torsion angles are 75.8(7) and 83.3(7)° and β of 79.6(3) and 87.3(4)°) and in anti-conformation as in the free L1, with the uncoordinated amide group rotated more with respect to the pyridine ring.

elements.content: The ORTEP presentation of asymmetric unit containing one L1 and HgI2 units is shown in a. The crystal structure of the 2D coordination polymer consists of a centrosymmetric [Hg(L1)­I2]2 dimeric unit (b). Each Hg­(II) ion is five coordinated, in a regular square pyramidal (τ = 0.06) coordination by two bridging and two terminal I and two, 2-connected L1 ligands. The latter is in anti-conformation vis-à-vis the amide oxygens and coordinates through pyridine N and one amide oxygen. The 2D coordination polymer contains linear antiparallel chains of edge sharing polyhedra (c), linked by L1 ligands in the bc plane and is topologically the same as complex 2 (d) with 32 member metallacycles. Intermolecular hydrogen bonding C11–H11B···O2 (SI, Table S6) and other intramolecular hydrogen bonding interactions further support this 2D array (vide infra). The amide groups of L1 are perpendicular to the pyridine ring (C4–C3–C6–O1 and C1–C2–C13–O2 torsion angles are −83.3(7) and 89.4(7)° and β of 86.9(4) and 85.9(4)°) and in anti-conformation as in the free L1, but the uncoordinated amide group is rotated more with respect to the pyridine ring.

Crystal Structure of [Hg(L1)I2]2 Complex 3 

The ORTEP presentation of asymmetric unit containing one L1 and HgI2 units is shown in a. The crystal structure of the 2D coordination polymer consists of a centrosymmetric [Hg(L1)I2]2 dimeric unit (b). Each Hg(II) ion is five coordinated, in a regular square pyramidal (τ = 0.06) coordination by two bridging and two terminal I and two, 2-connected L1 ligands. The latter is in anti-conformation vis-à-vis the amide oxygens and coordinates through pyridine N and one amide oxygen. The 2D coordination polymer contains linear antiparallel chains of edge sharing polyhedra (c), linked by L1 ligands in the bc plane and is topologically the same as complex 2 (d) with 32 member metallacycles. Intermolecular hydrogen bonding C11-H11B⋅⋅⋅O2 (SI, Table S6) and other intramolecular hydrogen bonding interactions further support this 2D array (vide infra). The amide groups of L1 are perpendicular to the pyridine ring (C4-C3-C6-O1 and C1-C2-C13-O2 torsion angles are -83.3(7) and 89.4(7)° and β of 86.9(4) and 85.9(4)°) and in anti-conformation as in the free L1, but the uncoordinated amide group is rotated more with respect to the pyridine ring.

elements.content: ORTEP diagram of the asymmetric unit is shown in (a). A perspective view (b, inset) shows that each metal ion is in a slightly distorted square pyramidal geometry (τ = 0.29) with two terminal chloride ions and one pyridine and two carbonyl oxygens from three different L2 ligands. Thus, L2 acts as a three-connecting linker. There are two alternating Hg2 L2 2 and Hg4 L2 4 units forming 14 and 26 member metallacyclic rings, respectively in the CP. Complex forms a brick work type 2D polymeric sheet (c). Topologically the structure composed of (1 0 1̅) layers, that form five-connected uninodal net having SP 2-periodic net type topology, with the point symbol {33.43.54}. The conformation of the L2 is anti. Relative to L1 the amide groups of L2 are less rotated with respect to the pyridine ring (β being 72.9(2) and 65.2(2)°) but are in anti conformation as well.

elements.content: ORTEP diagram of the asymmetric unit is shown in a. The complex is isostructural to complex 4. A perspective view of the complex (b) shows that each metal ion is in a slightly distorted square pyramidal geometry (τ 0.21) (b, inset), with two terminal bromide ions and three different L2 ligands. Each ligand is acting as three-connecting linker. The amide groups of L2 are less rotated with respect to the pyridine ring (β being 68.0(3) and 69.8(3)°) but are in anti-conformation as well. The arrangement forms a 2D brick work type coordination network with alternating Hg2 L2 2 and Hg4 L2 4 units. The μ3-bridging mode of L2 makes it a three-connected linker and Hg­(II) is a three-connected node (c) extending to form 2D sheets running diagonally to the bc plane. Topologically the structure is composed of (1 0 1̅) layers that form five-connected uninodal net having SP 2-periodic net type topology, with the point symbol {33.43.54}. The 2D sheet is assisted by various intra- and intermolecular C–H···X hydrogen-bonding interactions with carbonyl oxygens and bromide ion (vide infra)

elements.content: An ORTEP diagram (a) of the asymmetric unit and a perspective view of the complex (b) shows that it is a centrosymmetric dimeric complex with [Hg­(L2)­(I2)]2 unit. Each Hg­(II) has a near regular tetrahedral geometry with one terminal and two bridged iodide atoms and a pyridine coordinating L2 ligand molecule in anti-conformation. The amide groups of L2 are in anti-conformation with one rotated less than the other. Hg1···Hg1a (a = −x + 1/2, −y + 1/2 + 1, −z + 1) distance 3.876(1) Å found here is the shortest among this series. In the crystal structure C5–H5···O2 and C21–H21···O1 hydrogen bonding interactions and a strong LP···π interaction connects these dimers to give a 2D-sheet structure running parallel to the ab-plane (vide infra, b).

Crystal Structures of [Hg(L2)(I2)]2 (6)

An ORTEP diagram (a) of the asymmetric unit and a perspective view of the complex (b) shows that it is a centrosymmetric dimeric complex with [Hg(L2)(I2)]2 unit. Each Hg(II) has a near regular tetrahedral geometry with one terminal and two bridged iodide atoms and a pyridine coordinating L2 ligand molecule in anti-conformation. The amide groups of L2 are in anti-conformation with one rotated less than the other. Hg1⋅⋅⋅Hg1a (a = -x + 1/2, -y + 1/2 + 1, -z + 1) distance 3.876(1) Å found here is the shortest among this series. In the crystal structure C5-H5⋅⋅⋅O2 and C21-H21⋅⋅⋅O1 hydrogen bonding interactions and a strong LP⋅⋅⋅π interaction connects these dimers to give a 2D-sheet structure running parallel to the ab-plane (vide infra, b).

elements.content: Atomic and van der Waals radii of mercury­(II) are known to be 1.50 < r(Hg) < 1.73 Å. The van der Waal radii of halogens have been taken as Cl (1.75 Å), Br (1.85 Å), and I (1.98 Å) and that of N(1.55) and O(1.52). All distances smaller than the sum of van der Waals radii (<3.48, 3.58, 3.71 Å for Cl, Br, and I, respectively) have been considered to define the actual coordination number with the vdW of mercury taken as a mean value, 1.73 Å. A search of Hg–X­(bridging) bond distances in the Cambridge Structural Database (with the help of ConQuest version 1.14) reveals the reported ranges from 2.337 Å to 3.401 Å, 2.423 to 3.132 Å, and 2.706 to 3.488 Å for Cl, Br, and I, respectively. As expected the terminally bonded halide atoms have smaller distances than the bridging ones, in general and presently also. All bridging halides here are found unsymmetrically bridged, with one bond significantly smaller than the other.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

Bond Distances

Atomic and van der Waals radii of mercury(II) are known to be 1.50 < r(Hg) < 1.73 Å. The van der Waal radii of halogens have been taken as Cl (1.75 Å), Br (1.85 Å), and I (1.98 Å) and that of N(1.55) and O(1.52). All distances smaller than the sum of van der Waals radii (<3.48, 3.58, 3.71 Å for Cl, Br, and I, respectively) have been considered to define the actual coordination number with the vdW of mercury taken as a mean value, 1.73 Å. A search of Hg-X(bridging) bond distances in the Cambridge Structural Database (with the help of ConQuest version 1.14) reveals the reported ranges from 2.337 Å to 3.401 Å, 2.423 to 3.132 Å, and 2.706 to 3.488 Å for Cl, Br, and I, respectively. As expected the terminally bonded halide atoms have smaller distances than the bridging ones, in general and presently also. All bridging halides here are found unsymmetrically bridged, with one bond significantly smaller than the other.

elements.content: All chloride ions in complex 1 are bridging with their M–X bond lengths in the acceptable range (). Same is true for complexes 2 and 3. The longest Hg–Br­(B) known in the CSD is shorter than 3.361(2) Å reported here for complex 2, but as CSD also reports the longest Hg–Br (terminal) is 3.487 Å; therefore it has been retained, more so as it is less than the sum of vdW radii. However, the maximum Hg–I (bridging) distance 2.986 Å in complex 6 is much smaller than the sum of vdW distances, which is conspicuous in comparison to 4–5 (with no bridging halide). A higher covalent character of I increases its propensity to undergo bridging readily. Moreover an almost symmetrical I bridging in 6 in comparison to 3 is attributed to the lesser steric effects in the case of the former due to four coordinated Hg­(II).

However, the maximum Hg-I (bridging) distance 2.986 Å in complex 6 is much smaller than the sum of vdW distances, which is conspicuous in comparison to 4-5 (with no bridging halide). elements.content: Hg–N distances are in the range 2.501–3.498 Å (based on CSD search) found for mercury and pyridine/pyrazine complexes except for complex 1 where Hg–N 2.174(6) Å is significantly and surprisingly shorter and is attributed to the linear C16–H16C···N1­(py) (Figure S2, Table S4, SI) along the a axis. Since the coordination through N1 is also propagating the chains along the a axis, the hydrogen bonding contact acts cooperatively to bring N­(py) closer to Hg­(II). Hg–O distances found here are all within the range 2.434–3.649 Å but are invariably longer than the corresponding Hg–N distances, despite a smaller radius of O as compared to N. This has been observed earlier also. In fact Khavasi et al. have mentioned more than 100 reports (based on CSD search) having Hg–O longer than 3.00 Å. It is in accordance with a lesser affinity of harder O toward class b Hg­(II) metal ion, than N. In general the Hg–O distance here is curiously and finely tuned by the ∠C–O–Hg angle (θ) () when larger θ values are associated with smaller distances, bringing amide oxygen into a better overlapping position with the metal ion.

elements.content: The ligands can coordinate in three different modes using pyridine nitrogen and two amide oxygens (). The former has consistently been found in all the complexes, with or without the assistance from amide oxygens so that these may act as one, two, or three connecting linkers. The coordination modes I and II result in the formation of 2D CPs, while mode III forms dimers only. In mode I, invariably it is the amide group placed at position 4 which partcipates in coordination, akin to isonicotinamide analogues, accounting for the linearity of self-assemblies. Extension in the second dimension is accompalished by halide bridging. Mode II, on the other hand extends the CP in both the dimensions using the organic moiety only and thus has the primary structure directing effect, with anions largely being responsible for secondary effects. For modes I and III, the anion has the privilage of directing the primary structure with L guiding the secondary effects.
elements.clean_text:
Coordination Mode of Ligands

The ligands can coordinate in three different modes using pyridine nitrogen and two amide oxygens (). The former has consistently been found in all the complexes, with or without the assistance from amide oxygens so that these may act as one, two, or three connecting linkers. The coordination modes I and II result in the formation of 2D CPs, while mode III forms dimers only. In mode I, invariably it is the amide group placed at position 4 which partcipates in coordination, akin to isonicotinamide analogues, accounting for the linearity of self-assemblies. Extension in the second dimension is accompalished by halide bridging. Mode II, on the other hand extends the CP in both the dimensions using the organic moiety only and thus has the primary structure directing effect, with anions largely being responsible for secondary effects. For modes I and III, the anion has the privilage of directing the primary structure with L guiding the secondary effects.

elements.content: Not only is the role of counterions in the complex structure well documented but their effect on the self-assembly process via noncovalent interactions has also been found to be significant. Choice of halides as counteranions in the two series was made to explore both the aspects, i.e., direct influence of halide ion coordination to metal ion as well as their participation in a large number of weak C–H···X/LP···π interactions, on the resulting dimensionality and topology of the complex. The nature, size, and mode of coordination of the halide ions have not only affected the binding mode of the ligands and acted as the major factor in deciding the primary structure of the complex formed, but also influenced the secondary structures by generating various noncovalent interactions. While all three complexes 1–3 of propyl derivatives have 2-connected ligand L1, those of butyl derivatives 4–5 are 3- and 6 has 1-connected linker L2. Consequently 1–5 are 2D CPs containing five coordinated Hg­(II) ions, while 6 is a dinuclear complex with a four coordinated Hg­(II) ion. This may be attributed to the propensity of iodine atom to lower the coordination number of the Hg­(II) by increasing the electron density at the metal center because of the softer character of iodine compared to other halogen atoms. Another factor is the large size of the iodine atom relative to other halogen atoms. The large size of 5p orbitals of the iodine atom renders easy availability of its electrons to the metal atom. It also hinders the approach of more L2 ligands closer to the metal ion due to steric factors. Interestingly 3 also has a [Hg­(L)­I2]2 repeat unit in the polymer, signifying the importance and stability of a dinuclear moiety in both. A combination of the large butyl groups and halide ion in 6 compromises the denticity of L2 due to overwhelming steric factors. The loss is compensated by the more covalent nature of the Hg–I bond and C–H···O and LP···π, noncovalent interactions (vide infra).

Role of Anion

Not only is the role of counterions in the complex structure well documented but their effect on the self-assembly process via noncovalent interactions has also been found to be significant. Choice of halides as counteranions in the two series was made to explore both the aspects, i.e., direct influence of halide ion coordination to metal ion as well as their participation in a large number of weak C-H⋅⋅⋅X/LP⋅⋅⋅π interactions, on the resulting dimensionality and topology of the complex. The nature, size, and mode of coordination of the halide ions have not only affected the binding mode of the ligands and acted as the major factor in deciding the primary structure of the complex formed, but also influenced the secondary structures by generating various noncovalent interactions. While all three complexes 1-3 of propyl derivatives have 2-connected ligand L1, those of butyl derivatives 4-5 are 3- and 6 has 1-connected linker L2. Consequently 1-5 are 2D CPs containing five coordinated Hg(II) ions, while 6 is a dinuclear complex with a four coordinated Hg(II) ion. This may be attributed to the propensity of iodine atom to lower the coordination number of the Hg(II) by increasing the electron density at the metal center because of the softer character of iodine compared to other halogen atoms. Another factor is the large size of the iodine atom relative to other halogen atoms. The large size of 5p orbitals of the iodine atom renders easy availability of its electrons to the metal atom. It also hinders the approach of more L2 ligands closer to the metal ion due to steric factors. A combination of the large butyl groups and halide ion in 6 compromises the denticity of L2 due to overwhelming steric factors. The loss is compensated by the more covalent nature of the Hg-I bond and C-H⋅⋅⋅O and LP⋅⋅⋅π, noncovalent interactions (vide infra).

elements.content: Moreover the terminal or bridging mode of halide ions also affects the primary structures. Although 1–5 are all 2D polymers with dimeric repeat units created due to halide bridging between two closest Hg­(II) ions in 1–3, in 4–5 they are formed due to bridging L2 groups (with halides being terminal only). The latter are the ones to have three-connected L2 so as to recompense for bridging halide ions.

elements.content: The choice of ligands and counteranions in the present study is based upon maximizing the weak hydrogen-bonding interactions which do not contribute significantly toward any crystal structure on an individual basis but gain importance on the ground of sheer numbers. A plethora of weak interactions many times offsets the effect of fewer strong interactions. As put forth by Aakeroy “C–H···X interactions can tilt the balance between several options of stronger bonded networks thus acting as an important steering force in solid state assembly.” Presently, the fully substituted amide nitrogens lose the possibility of strong amide–amide H-bonding; nonetheless the presence of alkyl groups ensures a gain in terms of a large number of weak hydrogen-bonding interactions, in the periphery domain. Further the pyridyl nitrogen is invariably involved in connecting metal centers, whereas the amide groups may or may not coordinate and are important assets. This is not only because of the hydrogen-bonding ability of amide functionality and the rotational flexibility of the uncoordinated group, leading to various conformation but also due to the difference in hydrogen-bond acceptance of the metal coordinated amide group due to its changed basicity, in the ligand domain. Additionally the use of HgX2 increases the number of weak hydrogen-bonding interactions manifolds as polarity of metal–halogen bond (Mδ+―Xδ‑) makes halogen a better hydrogen bond acceptor than their carbon-bound counterparts. Various weak hydrogen-bonding interactions found in the present complexes and their effect on the overall crystal structure and dimensionality are discussed below.
elements.clean_text:
Noncovalent Interactions

The choice of ligands and counteranions in the present study is based upon maximizing the weak hydrogen-bonding interactions which do not contribute significantly toward any crystal structure on an individual basis but gain importance on the ground of sheer numbers. A plethora of weak interactions many times offsets the effect of fewer strong interactions. As put forth by Aakeroy "C-H⋅⋅⋅X interactions can tilt the balance between several options of stronger bonded networks thus acting as an important steering force in solid state assembly." Presently, the fully substituted amide nitrogens lose the possibility of strong amide-amide H-bonding; nonetheless the presence of alkyl groups ensures a gain in terms of a large number of weak hydrogen-bonding interactions, in the periphery domain. Further the pyridyl nitrogen is invariably involved in connecting metal centers, whereas the amide groups may or may not coordinate and are important assets. This is not only because of the hydrogen-bonding ability of amide functionality and the rotational flexibility of the uncoordinated group, leading to various conformation but also due to the difference in hydrogen-bond acceptance of the metal coordinated amide group due to its changed basicity, in the ligand domain. Additionally the use of HgX2 increases the number of weak hydrogen-bonding interactions manifolds as polarity of metal-halogen bond (Mδ+-Xδ-) makes halogen a better hydrogen bond acceptor than their carbon-bound counterparts. Various weak hydrogen-bonding interactions found in the present complexes and their effect on the overall crystal structure and dimensionality are discussed below.

elements.content: The polar nature of the M–X (metal–halogen) makes them good hydrogen bond acceptors, because of the increased electrostatic component for the D–H···X–M bond instead of the D–H···X–C bond. The strength of the D–H···X–M hydrogen bonds follows the order X = F ≫ Cl ≥ Br > I for D = C, N, O. This trend is understood as the polarity of the M–X bond follows a reverse order. It is indeed this hydrogen-bond acceptor tendency of the M–X bond that has attracted attention on a number of fronts like in metabolically important ion channels, in material chemistry, with different applications including thermochromic and magnetic materials. In the field of crystal engineering the supramolecular synthons utilize this hydrogen-bond acceptor tendency along with the directional properties of metal halides in the formation of hydrogen bonds and can be used to link molecular building blocks. The increased electronegativity of Hg in comparison to metals of lower atomic weight complicates the polarity of the Hg–X bond. However, an increased covalent character down the halogen group substantially decreases the polarity of the Hg–Br/I bond compared to the Hg–Cl bond. So a stronger H···X bonding is expected in chlorides. To compare the relative hydrogen bond acceptor tendency of metal bound halogens, three geometric parameters are used in the analysis of hydrogen bonds, H···X distance, and angles (D–H···X) and (H···X–M). The donor–acceptor pairs are put on a common scale by the use of normalized distances R HX = (d H···X)/(r H + r X), which was given by Lommerse et al. It allows a direct comparison of the bond acceptor capabilities of halogens and is calculated on the basis of van der Waals radii of H, F, Cl, Br, I atoms. Normalized distance vs angle plots that utilize R HX 3 vs 1-cos T(T = 180 – (D–H···X)) are used to investigate the geometrical preferences for the different hydrogen-bond types. The values of 1-cos T corresponds to the D–H···X angle, e.g., 1-cos T = 0 gives D–H···X = 180° and so on with similar correspondence for (H···X–M) angles. From a crystal engineering point terminal metal halides (except for F which is mostly isotropic) are highly directional hydrogen-bond acceptors and have angular preferences, with H···X–M lying in the close range of 90–130° due to a region with negative electrostatic potential around the halogen where it accepts the hydrogen.
elements.clean_text:
C-H⋅⋅⋅X Interactions

The polar nature of the M-X (metal-halogen) makes them good hydrogen bond acceptors, because of the increased electrostatic component for the D-H⋅⋅⋅X-M bond instead of the D-H⋅⋅⋅X-C bond. The strength of the D-H⋅⋅⋅X-M hydrogen bonds follows the order X = F ≫ Cl ≥ Br > I for D = C, N, O. This trend is understood as the polarity of the M-X bond follows a reverse order. It is indeed this hydrogen-bond acceptor tendency of the M-X bond that has attracted attention on a number of fronts like in metabolically important ion channels, in material chemistry, with different applications including thermochromic and magnetic materials. In the field of crystal engineering the supramolecular synthons utilize this hydrogen-bond acceptor tendency along with the directional properties of metal halides in the formation of hydrogen bonds and can be used to link molecular building blocks. The increased electronegativity of Hg in comparison to metals of lower atomic weight complicates the polarity of the Hg-X bond. However, an increased covalent character down the halogen group substantially decreases the polarity of the Hg-Br/I bond compared to the Hg-Cl bond. So a stronger H⋅⋅⋅X bonding is expected in chlorides. To compare the relative hydrogen bond acceptor tendency of metal bound halogens, three geometric parameters are used in the analysis of hydrogen bonds, H⋅⋅⋅X distance, and angles (D-H⋅⋅⋅X) and (H⋅⋅⋅X-M). The donor-acceptor pairs are put on a common scale by the use of normalized distances R HX = (d H⋅⋅⋅X)/(r H + r X), which was given by Lommerse et al. It allows a direct comparison of the bond acceptor capabilities of halogens and is calculated on the basis of van der Waals radii of H, F, Cl, Br, I atoms. Normalized distance vs angle plots that utilize R HX 3 vs 1-cos T(T = 180 - (D-H⋅⋅⋅X)) are used to investigate the geometrical preferences for the different hydrogen-bond types. The values of 1-cos T corresponds to the D-H⋅⋅⋅X angle, e.g., 1-cos T = 0 gives D-H⋅⋅⋅X = 180° and so on with similar correspondence for (H⋅⋅⋅X-M) angles. From a crystal engineering point terminal metal halides (except for F which is mostly isotropic) are highly directional hydrogen-bond acceptors and have angular preferences, with H⋅⋅⋅X-M lying in the close range of 90-130° due to a region with negative electrostatic potential around the halogen where it accepts the hydrogen.

elements.content: The mean normalized hydrogen bond distances RHX for C–H···X–M have been calculated (based on CSD) by Brammer et al. (given in for ca. R HX < 1.05, (R HX)3 ≤ 1.15) and analyzed to give the trend H···F≪ H···Cl ≅ H···Br < H···I which is the same as found in C–H···X–. Using the above-defined criterion and cut off such interactions found presently have been given in . As the R HX distances for two, one, and two interactions for complexes 1, 2, and 5, respectively, are less than the mean R HX reported earlier they therefore are termed as relatively stronger interactions (). In fact the shortest R HX distances in bromide complexes 2 and 5 are equal to the mean R HX distance found for H···Cl–M and that of chloride complex 1 is even less than the mean R HX distance (0.943 Å) for H···F–M interactions, indicating them to be relatively much stronger. This is interesting in the sense that Brammer et al. in their study only considered the terminal bound halide ions, whereas in the present case we have both terminal and bridged halide atoms, depending on the complex. Also that study did not include bifurcated or trifurcated hydrogen bond donors. In complex 1 Cl3 is not only triply bridging but is acting as a double hydrogen-bond acceptor to H1 and H2, making a weak and a strong contact. Similarly μ2-Cl4 accepts two hydrogen bonds, a weak and a strong one, from H1 and H7, respectively. The bifurcated hydrogen bonds with H1 are both weak. Similarly Br1 in complex 2 is bridging but makes a strong hydrogen bond with H16C. All Br atoms in complex 5 are terminal though, with H5 making a bifurcated but comparable hydrogen bond with Br2, albeit with a smaller D–H···X angle. As there is no literature available, including the bridged halides/multifurcated hydrogens to compare to, we therefore give our results as mere observations since their number is not sufficient to draw any generalizations. But it may be stated safely that the mode of coordination of the halide ion to the metal does not affect the RHX distance considerably; however it may influence the D–H···X angle making these interactions more directional. The data in again endorse the same trend H···Cl < H···Br < H···I, as noted earlier. In the case of complex 3, the R HX distance for the strongest interaction is close to that found earlier for H···X–C cases, which clearly reflect the diminished M–X bond polarity with iodide. In all five complexes these interactions help reinforce the 2D coordination polymers.

elements.content: These interactions are relatively rare but highly effective and of great importance in the host guest chemistry of biomolecules. High directional property of these interactions makes them very useful in crystal engineering of small molecular systems as well and have been found to be energetically favorable. Reedijk et al. have done a systematic study based on the CSD database considering electron deficient six-membered rings and various electron-rich atoms (O/N/halogens) and defined criterion to categorize them in terms of strength. Accordingly such interactions are considered strong if distances () from LP to the ring center, closest bond of the ring or closest atom of the ring are less than sum of the vdW radii of halogen and C atom, and they may be classified as delocalized, semilocalized, or localized, respectively. Apart from the distance, the angle subtended at the centroid (atom LP-centroid-plane, angle β in ), lying between 75 and 90° also indicates significantly strong interactions. According to these criterion, in our complexes 1 and 6, weak to moderate, semilocalized (SL) LP···π interactions have been seen, which further stabilize their 2D/dimeric molecular structures, respectively. Though the distances observed make them fall under weak interactions angle β lies close to 75° making them moderate enough to have some significant effect on the structure.

According to halogen bonding theory, the polarizability and the anisotropic character among the halogen atoms increase from F to I. In accordance with this it is more convenient for I than Br and Cl to have an electron-rich site at its equator region on forming a lone pair-π interaction with an electron-deficient ring. In 1 a highly directional and effective Hg–Cl4··· π or lone pair··· π interaction formed between μ2-Cl4 atom and the electron-deficient pyridine ring further sustains the polymeric chain running along the a-axis (a). In 6, Hg–I2··· π may be considered as one of the factors to stabilize a dimeric structure for complex 6 instead of a 1D CP which would have formed if I2 were bridging and coordinating to Hg­(II). It also gives additional support to the C–H···O bonded 1D chains running parallel to the b-axis (b). It is clear from the above discussion that coordinated anions whether they are terminal or bridged can participate in the self-assembly process by utilizing favorable noncovalent interactions that cooperatively control the topology of the final product.

For the present study C–H···π interactions were found in all four chloro and bromo complexes (Table S1, SI) between the alkyl groups and pyridine rings (). elements.content: Interactions involving aromatic systems though lack directionality and strength can contribute to self-assembly when extended structures contain building blocks with aromatic moieties. Aromatic rings show different orientation preferences, like stacked arrangement and an edge- or point-to-face T-shaped conformation. The stacking can also be an offset or slipped packing and need not be a perfect face-to-face arrangement of the rings. In a nonpolar π-arene system such as benzene, face-to-face alignment is unstable because of the electrostatic repulsion between the negatively charged clouds between the two rings. Here the T-shaped motif is found to be more stable because π–σ attraction is maximized in this geometry. Introduction of substituents or heteroatoms disturbs the uniform charge distribution in benzene resulting in the development of partial atomic charges and a permanent dipole which introduces electrostatic dipole–dipole and dipole–induced dipole interactions. In addition to this a metal atom which is coordinated to a nitrogen heteroatom further enhances the electron-withdrawing effect due to its positive charge. Hence, aromatic nitrogen heterocycles increase the tendency of the stack because of their low π-electron density. The stability order of the interaction involving two π-systems follows the order π-deficient−π-deficient > π-deficient−π-rich > π-rich−π-rich.

Interactions involving aromatic systems though lack directionality and strength can contribute to self-assembly when extended structures contain building blocks with aromatic moieties. Aromatic rings show different orientation preferences, like stacked arrangement and an edge- or point-to-face T-shaped conformation. The stacking can also be an offset or slipped packing and need not be a perfect face-to-face arrangement of the rings. In a nonpolar π-arene system such as benzene, face-to-face alignment is unstable because of the electrostatic repulsion between the negatively charged clouds between the two rings. Here the T-shaped motif is found to be more stable because π-σ attraction is maximized in this geometry. Introduction of substituents or heteroatoms disturbs the uniform charge distribution in benzene resulting in the development of partial atomic charges and a permanent dipole which introduces electrostatic dipole-dipole and dipole-induced dipole interactions. In addition to this a metal atom which is coordinated to a nitrogen heteroatom further enhances the electron-withdrawing effect due to its positive charge. Hence, aromatic nitrogen heterocycles increase the tendency of the stack because of their low π-electron density. The stability order of the interaction involving two π-systems follows the order π-deficient-π-deficient > π-deficient-π-rich > π-rich-π-rich.

elements.content: For understanding π–π interactions it is important to investigate the strength and orientation preference of the aromatic rings. In order to explore the effect of π–π interaction on the crystal packing of complex 4 and complex 5 containing ligand L 2 , we calculated the geometrical parameters that account for the amount of slippage of the two pyridine rings involved in π–π interactions. These geometric parameters were calculated for all complexes but only isostructural complexes 4 and 5 showed these interactions at reasonable Cg–Cg distances as shown in b,c and given in Table S2 (SI). It shows that a centroid distance of ∼4 Å an angle of ∼27° between the ring normal and the centroid vector corresponds to a horizontal displacement of ∼1.8 Å. It means that one py ring is shifted somewhat less than the 1,3-C-C distance in the ring from the face-to-face alignment to give weak interactions. In complexes 1, 2, and 3 the oxygen atom (CO group) lies 1.272, 1.316, 1.247 Å above the plane of pyridine ring with angles centered at oxygen atom (∠C–O–Hg) as 124, 138, 127°, respectively. In comparison to this the oxygen atom in complex 4 and 5 lies slightly toward the plane of pyridine ring, at 1.198, 1.203 Å, with shorter angles of 121, 119° in the 14-membered Hg2 L2 2 units, bringing the two rings closer for the interaction (b,c). The secondary effects of π–π interactions support the 2D network. A three-connecting ligand L2, giving brick wall type crystal structure of these two complexes with alternate 14 and 26 member metallacyclic rings, helps bring two adjacent pyridine rings face to face at a reasonable distance.

elements.content: The C–H···OC hydrogen bonding which forms a significant part of organic crystal engineering is also equally important in metal–organic systems because the same functional groups are present as part of organic ligands. Though flexible and directional in nature, the nonclassical C–H···O hydrogen bonds are weak, because of the smaller electronegativity difference between C and H and the weak H-bond acceptor ability of the -CO group. In contrast to van der Waals forces, the C–H···O hydrogen bonds are directional in nature and also can have an attractive influence beyond the van der Waals contacts. Like strong hydrogen bonds D–H···A where D, A = N or O, the hydrogen bonds containing C–H···O interactions can be the part of structure-directing recognition motifs, so-called “supramolecular synthons” which involve noncovalent hydrogen bonding interactions that can lead to hydrogen bonding frameworks of various dimensionality. The metal atom can guide the formation of hydrogen bonds between neighboring molecules by coordinating to a rigid ligand having hydrogen bonding groups present at the periphery domain.
elements.clean_text:
C-H⋅⋅⋅O(amide) Interactions

The C-H⋅⋅⋅OC hydrogen bonding which forms a significant part of organic crystal engineering is also equally important in metal-organic systems because the same functional groups are present as part of organic ligands. Though flexible and directional in nature, the nonclassical C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds are weak, because of the smaller electronegativity difference between C and H and the weak H-bond acceptor ability of the -CO group. In contrast to van der Waals forces, the C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds are directional in nature and also can have an attractive influence beyond the van der Waals contacts. Like strong hydrogen bonds D-H⋅⋅⋅A where D, A = N or O, the hydrogen bonds containing C-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions can be the part of structure-directing recognition motifs, so-called "supramolecular synthons" which involve noncovalent hydrogen bonding interactions that can lead to hydrogen bonding frameworks of various dimensionality. The metal atom can guide the formation of hydrogen bonds between neighboring molecules by coordinating to a rigid ligand having hydrogen bonding groups present at the periphery domain.

elements.content: Presently both coordinated and uncoordinated amide oxygens have been involved in inter- and intramolecular C–H···O hydrogen-bonding interactions (Tables S3–S9). The −CO group here may be considered in the ligand or the periphery domain depending on its role in coordination. In complexes 1–5 the 2D coordination polymer is supported by various C–H···O interactions involving C–H donors at the periphery domain of the complex. However, in complex 6 they have the significant role of changing the dimensionality of the crystal structure. Both amide oxygens in the dimeric coordination complex 6 are free and take part in hydrogen-bonding. C5–H5···O2 hydrogen-bonding interactions () connect these dimers to give 1D hydrogen-bonded tapes along the b-axis, C21–H21···O1 hydrogen-bonding interactions in turn connect these tapes (b) to give a 2D-sheet structure running parallel to the ab-plane. These interactions create R4 4(24) and R2 2(18) supramolecular synthons in the crystal structure. They become the major force to extend a simple dimeric molecular structure to a 2D crystal structure with the help from aforementioned LP···π interactions. Both amide oxygens in 1 are involved in intramolecular hydrogen bonding, while in 2 and 3 the free amide oxygens support 1D propagation by forming catemers synthons due to intermolecular hydrogen bonding (). In complexes 4 and 5, C–H···O intermolecular hydrogen-bonding forms R 4 2(8) supramolecular synthons employing one of the coordinating oxygens (Figure S4, SI) in the larger metalacycle. The intramolecular C–H···O interactions in these complexes invariably have shorter H···O and C···O distances and smaller C–H···O angles, whereas the intermolecular interactions have longer distances and wider angles. Collectively, however, they are scattered over a wider range of distances and angles, which is typical of such “soft” interactions, as they can be easily deformed. There is no clear trend in the hydrogen-bond distances/angles between the coordinating and noncoordinating amide oxygens. This indicates that metal coordination does not exert any significant electronic influence on the basicity of the amide oxygen unlike the coordinating carbonyl group which becomes a much better hydrogen-bond acceptor on metal coordination due to the back bonding. This may be because M–O (amide) bonding is weak here due to steric factors and the hardness of oxygen and also any gain in the basicity of amide group is balanced by the loss incurred due to the lack of resonance stabilization of the amide group on metal binding.

elements.content: Metallophilic interactions have recently been employed to prepare finite or infinite metal chains for closed shell d10 metal ions. While such interactions are well documented for Au­(I), Ag­(I), and Cu­(I), evidence for strong mercurophilic interactions is rather debatable despite there being many reports for short Hg­(II)···Hg­(II) distances. Mercurophilic interactions have been reported/calculated with Hg···Hg distances ranging from 3.570 Å to 4.484 Å. The wide range may be partially attributed to the acceptable value of vdW radius of mercury which has been reported from 1.71 (vide supra) up to 2.2 Å with the latter being thought as a better estimate than others. Though Hg···Hg distance as short as 3.41 Å has never been reported, many halide bridged Hg based structures, with ubiquitous Hg2X2 bridges, are known to have Hg···Hg inetarctions within this range. However, compounds with these interactions leading to linear metal chains are rather rare. Lu et al. have discussed them and described the formation of linear and zig-zag chains of mercury metal ions with distances 3.77, 3.94, and 4.01 Å for their own compounds. They also carefully analyzed that halide bridging alone is not sufficient for the formation of linear mercury chains, with shorter distances but noncovalent interactions (π···π in their case) having a significant effect on such architectures.
elements.clean_text:
Mercurophilic Interactions

Metallophilic interactions have recently been employed to prepare finite or infinite metal chains for closed shell d10 metal ions. While such interactions are well documented for Au(I), Ag(I), and Cu(I), evidence for strong mercurophilic interactions is rather debatable despite there being many reports for short Hg(II)⋅⋅⋅Hg(II) distances. Mercurophilic interactions have been reported/calculated with Hg⋅⋅⋅Hg distances ranging from 3.570 Å to 4.484 Å. The wide range may be partially attributed to the acceptable value of vdW radius of mercury which has been reported from 1.71 (vide supra) up to 2.2 Å with the latter being thought as a better estimate than others. Though Hg⋅⋅⋅Hg distance as short as 3.41 Å has never been reported, many halide bridged Hg based structures, with ubiquitous Hg2X2 bridges, are known to have Hg⋅⋅⋅Hg inetarctions within this range. However, compounds with these interactions leading to linear metal chains are rather rare. Lu et al. have discussed them and described the formation of linear and zig-zag chains of mercury metal ions with distances 3.77, 3.94, and 4.01 Å for their own compounds. They also carefully analyzed that halide bridging alone is not sufficient for the formation of linear mercury chains, with shorter distances but noncovalent interactions (π⋅⋅⋅π in their case) having a significant effect on such architectures.

elements.content: Presently the 2D CP complex 1 with extensive chloride bridging is of particular interest in this regard. The unique architecture of the complex offers infinite, linear zig-zag metal chains (Hg1···Hg1···Hg2···Hg2···Hg1···Hg1) with Hg1···Hg2 3.81, Hg2···Hg2 3.96 and Hg1···Hg1 4.01 Å, ∠Hg1···Hg1···Hg2 117°, ∠Hg1···Hg2···Hg2 92°, along the b axis (). A longer Hg1···Hg1 interaction at 4.36 Å with Hg1···Hg1···Hg1 119° and Hg2···Hg1···Hg1 117° joins these linear chains to form a 2D network of metal chains. Thus, mercurophilic interactions support the original 2D topology formed due to the coordination bond. While extensive halide bridging might be responsible for the propagation of 1D linear chains, their extension in the other dimension is clearly supported by the LP···π interactions between the Cl4 and Py ring, discussed above. The (μ3-Cl3, μ2-Cl4-Hg2) moieties in the Hg10 rectangular metallacycles (∼11.5 × 7.2 Å, distances between the closest Hg­(II) ions) are held together by the organic ligand. The ensuing LP···π, strong C–H···Cl (a and a) and linear C16–H16···N1 (Figure S2, SI) interactions are responsible for constricting the metallacycles breadthwise, shortening the Hg1···Hg1 distance () parallel to the a axis.
elements.clean_text: Presently the 2D CP complex 1 with extensive chloride bridging is of particular interest in this regard. The unique architecture of the complex offers infinite, linear zig-zag metal chains (Hg1⋅⋅⋅Hg1⋅⋅⋅Hg2⋅⋅⋅Hg2⋅⋅⋅Hg1⋅⋅⋅Hg1) with Hg1⋅⋅⋅Hg2 3.81, Hg2⋅⋅⋅Hg2 3.96 and Hg1⋅⋅⋅Hg1 4.01 Å, ∠Hg1⋅⋅⋅Hg1⋅⋅⋅Hg2 117°, ∠Hg1⋅⋅⋅Hg2⋅⋅⋅Hg2 92°, along the b axis (). A longer Hg1⋅⋅⋅Hg1 interaction at 4.36 Å with Hg1⋅⋅⋅Hg1⋅⋅⋅Hg1 119° and Hg2⋅⋅⋅Hg1⋅⋅⋅Hg1 117° joins these linear chains to form a 2D network of metal chains. Thus, mercurophilic interactions support the original 2D topology formed due to the coordination bond. While extensive halide bridging might be responsible for the propagation of 1D linear chains, their extension in the other dimension is clearly supported by the LP⋅⋅⋅π interactions between the Cl4 and Py ring, discussed above. The (μ3-Cl3, μ2-Cl4-Hg2) moieties in the Hg10 rectangular metallacycles (~11.5 × 7.2 Å, distances between the closest Hg(II) ions) are held together by the organic ligand. The ensuing LP⋅⋅⋅π, strong C-H⋅⋅⋅Cl (a and a) and linear C16-H16⋅⋅⋅N1 (Figure S2, SI) interactions are responsible for constricting the metallacycles breadthwise, shortening the Hg1⋅⋅⋅Hg1 distance () parallel to the a axis.

elements.content: Complex 6 also shows Hg1···Hg1 interactions within the dimer at a distance of 3.88 Å, which is within the conceivable range for such interactions. The other two complexes, having a dimeric structure due to bridging halides, are 2 and 3, with Hg···Hg distances of 4.28 and 4.33 Å much longer than 6. The difference is clearly due to a change in coordination number from five to four in the latter.

elements.content: In this paper we have described the self-assembly of the HgX2 (X = Cl, Br, I) and divergent ligands L1 and L2 based upon 3,4-pyridinedicarboxamides. The dimensionality and topology of the self-assembled systems are shown to be an interesting outcome of the divergent nature of ligands, coordination mode of anions, steric factors, hydrogen bonding, and other noncovalent interactions. A combination of labile Hg­(II) metal ion having ubiquitous Hg2X2 bridges and divergent ligands has given the expected 2D CPs. A ligand vs anion competition for the metal ion is imminent where steric congestion becomes overwhelming like in complexes (4–6) with bigger butyl groups. The primary structure is guided by size, polarizability, and covalency of the anion with bridging I ion being preferred over the tritopic ligand resulting in the only dimer in the two series. The coordinated anions whether they are terminal or bridged can participate in the self-assembly process by utilizing favorable noncovalent interactions that cooperatively control the topology of the final product. For example, the 2D hydrogen-bonded network of 6 owing to the C–H···O interactions forming R2 2(18) and R4 4(24) synthons and a highly effective, semilocalized LP···π noncovalent interaction. 2D CPs in 1–5 are strengthened by various modest noncovalent interactions such as C–H···X (X = Cl, Br, I), C–H···O­(amide), C–H­(alkyl)···π and π–π. The unique 2D metal ion architecture, seen in the 2D self-assembled CP of 1, is also formed and supported by various noncovalent interactions like mercurophilic, LP···π, C–H···Cl, C–H···N­(py). The strength of C–H···X interactions is found to be independent of bi- or trifurcated participation of halide or hydrogen atoms in this H-bonding.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this paper we have described the self-assembly of the HgX2 (X = Cl, Br, I) and divergent ligands L1 and L2 based upon 3,4-pyridinedicarboxamides. The dimensionality and topology of the self-assembled systems are shown to be an interesting outcome of the divergent nature of ligands, coordination mode of anions, steric factors, hydrogen bonding, and other noncovalent interactions. A combination of labile Hg(II) metal ion having ubiquitous Hg2X2 bridges and divergent ligands has given the expected 2D CPs. A ligand vs anion competition for the metal ion is imminent where steric congestion becomes overwhelming like in complexes (4-6) with bigger butyl groups. The primary structure is guided by size, polarizability, and covalency of the anion with bridging I ion being preferred over the tritopic ligand resulting in the only dimer in the two series. The coordinated anions whether they are terminal or bridged can participate in the self-assembly process by utilizing favorable noncovalent interactions that cooperatively control the topology of the final product. For example, the 2D hydrogen-bonded network of 6 owing to the C-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions forming R2 2(18) and R4 4(24) synthons and a highly effective, semilocalized LP⋅⋅⋅π noncovalent interaction. 2D CPs in 1-5 are strengthened by various modest noncovalent interactions such as C-H⋅⋅⋅X (X = Cl, Br, I), C-H⋅⋅⋅O(amide), C-H(alkyl)⋅⋅⋅π and π-π. The unique 2D metal ion architecture, seen in the 2D self-assembled CP of 1, is also formed and supported by various noncovalent interactions like mercurophilic, LP⋅⋅⋅π, C-H⋅⋅⋅Cl, C-H⋅⋅⋅N(py). The strength of C-H⋅⋅⋅X interactions is found to be independent of bi- or trifurcated participation of halide or hydrogen atoms in this H-bonding.

elements.content: All the commercially available chemicals were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification. All solvents were dried by standard methods. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Perkin–Elmer model 2400 CHN analyzer. The 1H NMR spectra were produced using DMSO-d 6 with TMS as an internal reference on a JEOL-FT NMR-300 MHz spectrophotometer. The infrared spectra (KBr pellet) were recorded using PerkinElmer FT-IR C92035 spectrophotometer in the range 400–4000 cm–1. HRMS spectra were recorded on a Bruker’s microTOF-QII spectrophotometer. Single crystal structural X-ray diffraction studies were carried out on a Bruker’s Apex-II CCD diffractometer using Mo Kα (λ = 0.71069 Å) at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All the commercially available chemicals were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification. All solvents were dried by standard methods. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer model 2400 CHN analyzer. The 1H NMR spectra were produced using DMSO-d 6 with TMS as an internal reference on a JEOL-FT NMR-300 MHz spectrophotometer. The infrared spectra (KBr pellet) were recorded using PerkinElmer FT-IR C92035 spectrophotometer in the range 400-4000 cm-1. HRMS spectra were recorded on a Bruker's microTOF-QII spectrophotometer. Single crystal structural X-ray diffraction studies were carried out on a Bruker's Apex-II CCD diffractometer using Mo Kα (λ = 0.71069 Å) at room temperature.

elements.content: In a 250 mL RBF containing (5.9 mmol, 1.0 g) of 3,4-pyridine dicarboxylic acid in DMF (2 mL), SOCl2 (30 mL) was added, and the reaction was refluxed for 2 h. After the solution became clear, dry toluene was added, and the excess of SOCl2 was removed by vacuum distillation. The reaction mixture was cooled down subsequently to room temperature and pyridine (17 mmol, 1.4 mL), and N,N-diisopropyl (15 mmol, 2.1 mL for L1) or N,N-diisobutyl-amine (15 mmol, 2.6 mL for L2) were added to the reaction mixture and stirred for 1 h. The solution was left undisturbed overnight. The organic layer was washed with distilled water followed by a saturated solution of NaHCO3 thrice and dried over Na2SO4. A slow evaporation gave light-brown colored crystals for L1 while L2 remained a viscous liquid.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Ligands

 N,N,N',N'-Tetraisopropyl-3,4-pyridinedicarboxamide (L1), N,N,N',N'-Tetraisobutyl-3,4-pyridinedicarboxamide (L2)

In a 250 mL RBF containing (5.9 mmol, 1.0 g) of 3,4-pyridine dicarboxylic acid in DMF (2 mL), SOCl2 (30 mL) was added, and the reaction was refluxed for 2 h. After the solution became clear, dry toluene was added, and the excess of SOCl2 was removed by vacuum distillation. The reaction mixture was cooled down subsequently to room temperature and pyridine (17 mmol, 1.4 mL), and N,N-diisopropyl (15 mmol, 2.1 mL for L1) or N,N-diisobutyl-amine (15 mmol, 2.6 mL for L2) were added to the reaction mixture and stirred for 1 h. The solution was left undisturbed overnight. The organic layer was washed with distilled water followed by a saturated solution of NaHCO3 thrice and dried over Na2SO4. A slow evaporation gave light-brown colored crystals for L1 while L2 remained a viscous liquid.

Single-Crystal X-ray DiffractionX-ray Crystallography

X-ray quality crystals were obtained by slow evaporation from methanol or methanol/acetonitrile mixture. X-ray data of L1 and (1–6) complexes were processed by SAINT. Lorentz and polarization effects and empirical absorption corrections were applied using SADABS from Bruker. The structures were solved by direct methods, using SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares refinement methods based on F2, using SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. All hydrogen atoms were fixed geometrically with their U iso values 1.2 times of phenylene carbons. All calculations were performed using Wingx package. Crystal data and structure refinements are given in . Refinement of 1 showed residual electron density of ∼7 e·Å3 (at 1.93 Å) from Cl4 and a peak of ∼4 e·Å3 very close (0.21 Å) from Cl2. Inclusion of the former as C/N/O atoms gave a chemically irrational structure. Attempts to refine it as disordered Cl4 by splitting it at the two positions with variable sofs did not help as Cl4 moved to its original position with full site occupancy. A use of SQUEEZE routine of PLATON, 155 to this data did not show any voids or SAVs (solvent accessible voids) which suggested that there is no unaccounted electron density. Therefore, these peaks were ignored as spurious peaks which may be an outcome of any unresolved disorder in the corresponding chlorine atoms. However, the structure did not show any disorder except for two terminal methyl groups C18, C19. Refinement of complex 5 showed a residual electron density peak of ∼4 e·Å3 close to (0.77 Å) from the heavy atom Hg which may be due to a series termination error because the appropriate absorption correction had been applied. CIFs of both the structures showed A level alerts due to this. Residual peaks (∼1–2.5 e·Å3) were also seen around Hg in all other complexes and in 3 and 6 around I as well for the same reason and resulted in some ‘C’ level alerts. Structures of L1, 1, 3, 4, and 6 showed a small to moderate amount of disorder in alkyl groups in terms of high thermal parameters. As this is typical of the terminal alkyl groups, this disorder was not resolved. Only in L1 the refinement was converged using restraints over C–C distances.

cln_elements.content:
In a 250 mL RBF containing (5.9 mmol, 1.0 g) of 3,4-pyridine dicarboxylic acid in DMF (2 mL), SOCl2 (30 mL) was added, and the reaction was refluxed for 2 h. After the solution became clear, dry toluene was added, and the excess of SOCl2 was removed by vacuum distillation. The reaction mixture was cooled down subsequently to room temperature and pyridine (17 mmol, 1.4 mL), and N,N-diisopropyl (15 mmol, 2.1 mL for L1) or N,N-diisobutyl-amine (15 mmol, 2.6 mL for L2) were added to the reaction mixture and stirred for 1 h. The solution was left undisturbed overnight. The organic layer was washed with distilled water followed by a saturated solution of NaHCO3 thrice and dried over Na2SO4. A slow evaporation gave light-brown colored crystals for L1 while L2 remained a viscous liquid.

Synthesis of Complexes of HgCl<sub>2</sub> with <bold>L1</bold>–<bold>L2</bold> [[Hg­(<bold>L1</bold>)­Cl<sub>2</sub>]­[HgCl<sub>2</sub>] (<bold>1</bold>), [Hg­(<bold>L2</bold>)­Cl<sub>2</sub>] (<bold>4</bold>)]

In a 50 mL RBF, L1 (0.30 mmol, 0.10 g) and HgCl2 (0.45 mmol, 0.12 g) (for 1) or L2 (0.26 mmol, 0.10 g) and HgCl2 (0.38 mmol, 0.10g) (for 4) were dissolved in a methanol–acetonitrile mixture (1:1) and refluxed for half an hour. The reaction mixture was transferred to a conical flask, where slow evaporation gave colorless crystals for (1) and (4), within a week.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Ligands

 N,N,N',N'-Tetraisopropyl-3,4-pyridinedicarboxamide (L1), N,N,N',N'-Tetraisobutyl-3,4-pyridinedicarboxamide (L2)

In a 250 mL RBF containing (5.9 mmol, 1.0 g) of 3,4-pyridine dicarboxylic acid in DMF (2 mL), SOCl2 (30 mL) was added, and the reaction was refluxed for 2 h. After the solution became clear, dry toluene was added, and the excess of SOCl2 was removed by vacuum distillation. The reaction mixture was cooled down subsequently to room temperature and pyridine (17 mmol, 1.4 mL), and N,N-diisopropyl (15 mmol, 2.1 mL for L1) or N,N-diisobutyl-amine (15 mmol, 2.6 mL for L2) were added to the reaction mixture and stirred for 1 h. The solution was left undisturbed overnight. The organic layer was washed with distilled water followed by a saturated solution of NaHCO3 thrice and dried over Na2SO4. A slow evaporation gave light-brown colored crystals for L1 while L2 remained a viscous liquid.

Synthesis of Complexes of HgCl2 with L1-L2 [[Hg(L1)Cl2][HgCl2] (1), [Hg(L2)Cl2] (4)]

In a 50 mL RBF, L1 (0.30 mmol, 0.10 g) and HgCl2 (0.45 mmol, 0.12 g) (for 1) or L2 (0.26 mmol, 0.10 g) and HgCl2 (0.38 mmol, 0.10g) (for 4) were dissolved in a methanol-acetonitrile mixture (1:1) and refluxed for half an hour. The reaction mixture was transferred to a conical flask, where slow evaporation gave colorless crystals for (1) and (4), within a week.

Anal. Calcd for (2), C19H31Br2HgN3O2 (%): C, 32.89; H, 4.50; N, 6.06; Found: C, 32.06; H, 4.55; N, 6.84. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1) (): 2970 (s), 1633 (s), 1445 (s), 1344 (s), 1156 (s), 847 (s).

Anal. Calcd for (5), C23H39Br2HgN3O2 (%): C, 36.83; H, 5.24; N, 5.60; Found: C, 36.37; H, 5.65; N, 5.65. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1) (): 2965 (s), 1646 (s), 1451 (s), 1261 (s), 1098 (s), 850 (s).

Synthesis of Complex of HgI2 with L1-L2 [[Hg(L1)I2]2 (3), [Hg(L2)I2]2 (6)]

Methanolic solution of HgI2 (0.45 mmol, 0.20 g) and L1 (0.30 mmol, 0.10 g) for (3) or HgI2 (0.38 mmol, 0.17 g) and L2 (0.26 mmol, 0.10 g) in acetonitrile, for (6), were added to a 50 mL RBF, and the mixture was refluxed for 1 h. The reaction mixture was transferred to a conical flask, where slow evaporation gave colorless crystals within a week.

Hg1­(magenta), Hg2 (cyan) in panels b–d.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) ORTEP diagram of the asymmetric unit for complex (1), (b) 2D coordination network due to 2 connected L1 and halide bridging in the ab plane, (c) alternate chains of edge sharing octahedrons and square pyramids, (d) topology of the complex with alternating stairs and ladders. Hg1(magenta), Hg2 (cyan) in panels b-d.

cln_elements.content: (a) ORTEP diagram of the asymmetric unit of complex 2, (b) polyhedral representation of 2D CP showing edge-sharing square pyramids in antiparallel fashion, (c) topology of the complex showing two- and four-connected linker and metal nodes, respectively. Terminal bromides are omitted.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (a) ORTEP diagram of the asymmetric unit of complex 2, (b) polyhedral representation of 2D CP showing edge-sharing square pyramids in antiparallel fashion, (c) topology of the complex showing two- and four-connected linker and metal nodes, respectively. Terminal iodides are omitted.

metadata.title:
First Report on
Crystal Engineering of Hg(II) Halides
with Fully Substituted 3,4-Pyridinedicarboxamides: Generation of Two-Dimensional
Coordination Polymers and Linear Zig-Zag Chains of Mercury Metal Ions
